Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Chandler-Gilbert Community College in Arizona is continuing its successful program, called High-Tech Transfer Program Scholars (HTTPS), in which academically talented but financially needy students in science, engineering, computer science, and mathematics are given financial and academic support to prepare them to achieve an associate's degree or transfer credits and continue on to contribute to the STEM workforce. Special attention is paid to recruiting and supporting students underrepresented in the STEM disciplines, particularly drawing on the regional population of Hispanic and Native American students, thereby broadening the impact of this program. Women and persons with disabilities will likewise be encouraged to participate in the HTTPS program's academic and extra-academic activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the CGCC HTTPS Project is to provide specialized educational opportunities and services for full-time financial-aid eligible students with majors or program interests pursuing degrees in the fields of science, engineering, math and computer science engineering, particularly those traditionally underrepresented in these fields: Hispanics, African-Americans, Native Americans, women, and/or persons with disabilities. All HTTPS recipients will have an ultimate goal to complete an Associate Degree and/or transfer to a Baccalaureate Degree-granting institution, and a long term goal of entering the workforce in their skill area. 

All the objectives and goals for this project have been met for the duration of this grant.   We were able to provide at least 22 scholarships per semester to academically talented and financially needy students pursuing degrees in science, engineering, computer science engineering, or mathematics.  

More 90% of HTTPS recipients more satisfactory progress (enrolled full-time with a minimum GPA of 2.85) in a targeted STEM area leading to an associate degree or transfer credits during most of each semester for which they receive a scholarship.

At least 25% of HTTPS recipients were from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines (Hispanics, African-Americans, Native Americans, women, and individuals with disabilities) and

Finall most of HTTPS recipients participated in at least 75% of Project meetings, special events, services, and activities during semesters for which they receive scholarship support.


Last Modified: 08/01/2016
Modified by: Bassam Matar

All the objectives and goals for this project have been met for the duration of this grant. We were able to provide at least 22 scholarships per semester to academically talented and financially needy students pursuing degrees in science, engineering, computer science engineering, or mathematics. More 90% of HTTPS recipients more satisfactory progress (enrolled full-time with a minimum GPA of 2.85) in a targeted STEM area leading to an associate degree or transfer credits during most of each semester for which they receive a scholarship. At least 25% of HTTPS recipients were from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines (Hispanics, African-Americans, Native Americans, women, and individuals with disabilities) and Finall most of HTTPS recipients participated in at least 75% of Project meetings, special events, services, and activities during semesters for which they receive scholarship support.
